Award.AwardTitle: Implementation Grant: Development of Multidepartmental, Multidisciplinary Concentrations at Tuskegee University

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The "Development of Multidepartmental,Multidisciplinary Concentrations at Tuskegee University" project seeks to reform the approach to biology instruction by infusing a strong genomic-bioinformatics and biophysics focus into the current biology curriculum and linking it to a collaboratory research experience that will promote critical thinking, enhance quantitative skills, ascertain mastery of integration of knowledge learned, and illustrate the interconnectedness of STEM disciplines for all students.
The overarching goal of this project is to develop a genomic-bioinformatic and biophysics stream of concentration by developing requisite courses including Microbial Genomics, Introductory Bioinformatics, Computational Genomics, with dry and wet labs with genomics data search using computers; by integrating genomics and bioinformatics modules into existing courses; by implementing and evaluating the newly developed courses using wet/dry project collaboratories and computer-based lectures; and by disseminating the results of these efforts among undergraduate faculty in general and those at HBCUs and MSIs in particular.
This effort will result in an increase in the quality of educational instruction in biology, production of a cadre of very talented students (particularly minority students) who are capable of employing diverse aspects of mathematics and physics to answer biological questions, and better-trained faculty who are capable of deploying pedagogical approaches that infect students with an enthusiasm for scientific discovery. The transformation of the biology curriculum will have the outcome of effecting changes across the natural and physical sciences departments and increasing the dialogue of how best to train students for the practice of science in the 21st century.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Research and Education Activities:

I. INTELLECTUAL MERIT

The NSF-funded HBCU-UP Award, “Implementation Grant: Development of Multi-departmental, Multidisciplinary Concentrations at Tuskegee University (TU)” was active from 2009-2015.  Over the 6 years of the grant, more than 34 faculty, 6 Post-doctoral scientists, 17 graduate students, 162 undergraduates, summer interns were directly supported, and there were academic collaborations with more than a dozen universities and research centers.  The project hired five permanent positions and several workshops were presented each year.  Several high impact bundles of equipment were purchased by the grant, including 40 computers and the software to establish a High Performance Computing lab, an Academic Achievement Lab in Quantitation, a Learning Research Center, MATLAB  software and supporting instructional equipment, a Laser and Optics lab, a 4' Chemical Fume Hood, a Gear Drive Planetary Ball Mill to develop nanoparticles, a Chamber Furnace for heating and annealing advanced materials, a Horizon Fuel Cell Kit for use in producing clean alternative energy, a Physics Undergraduate Instructional and Research Laboratory, and a LIBS spectrophotometer/YAG laser system to analyze the trace elements.  Faculty participated in professional development at eight institutions. A joint collaboration between TU, Lehigh University and Pennsylvania State University offered a glass course Physics 499 for students at Tuskegee University, 'The Science and Applications of Glass'. The faculty also taught courses on Advanced Physics and Solid State Materials.

Instructional synergy was developed across math, chemistry, physics, computing and biology.  This required the development of STEM Year 1 and Year 2 Teams to focus on the alignment of the science curricula; development of mandatory recitations to reinforce concepts and echo them across the STEM courses; the required use of iClickers; mandatory 2- hour recitations for Chemistry and Biology courses; the effective use of Blackboard; and weekly quizzes; and the use of embedded questions during each lecture to assess knowledge acquisition and conceptualization. This resulted in a two-fold increase in class attendance (from 40% to 80%) and a steady positive slope for overall improvement in academic performance among first-year students.  The use of recitations resulted in only 40% of students repeating introductory courses. This was a significant improvement compared to previous years when repeat rates were as high as 60%. iClickers doubled classroom participation.  Eight interdisciplinary courses were created or revised. New minor concentrations extended the impacts of the bioinformatics curricular enhancements.  Joint collaborations of students and teachers from various STEM disciplines also evolved. Students benefited from the improved course content and also from participating in authentic research activities with participating faculty. Four project labs were developed in Neuroscience, Immunology, Bioinformatics, and Parasitology. We also broadened and intensified SWORD (Survival While On the Road to Degree/Doctorate) to improve access and retention.

The Office of Undergraduate Research (OUR), which had more than 1200 visits by students, offered two new programs supported by HBCU-UP; the Joint Annual Research Symposium (JARS), and the Interdisciplinary Meeting of Professionals for the Awareness of Careers and Training of Undergraduate Students (IMPACTUS). JARS allowed students to present research they conducted in a myriad of disciplines. OUR also organized a Science Summit and a new Distinguished Scholar Seminar Series. To date, JARS has attracted more than 2,000 undergraduates and graduate student researchers. IMPACTUS has supported hundreds of students to network with research/science professionals. OUR helped several hundred students find summer internships and to conduct research at more than 50 different universities and research centers.   More than 100 students were accepted into graduate or professional schools because of the HBCU UP grant.  The OUR also hosted 15 graduate school recruiters to help students with career planning.

II. BROADER IMPACTS

HBCU-UP supported more than 300 undergraduate and graduate, students directly, and another 1,200 students indirectly via specialized learning centers and courses.  Ninety-five percent of these were from underrepresented minority backgrounds.  Using near-peer mentoring, HBCU-UP supported students and faculty also mentored more than 700 summer high school interns and visiting undergraduate students from nearly every U.S. State and territory.  The majority of these students were also from URM backgrounds. HBCU-UP supported students and faculty also volunteered in multiple community service initiatives, like gardens, small farmers, science, fairs and community STEM education programs.  Faculty also delivered and demonstrated clean energy and environment technologies at the TU Business and Engineering (TUBE) conference organized by the students, and demonstrated research/science techniques to local high school teachers via summer workshops.  More than 200 presentations were made by students at local, regional and national symposia and conferences.  Three students successfully completed both the requirements for the biology major and the education major. This made them eligible to be accepted in the Biology Educators program. As a requirement of the program, the students taught for one year in a high needs school. They later pursued teaching careers in Alabama, California, and Georgia. The OUR also created several OUR/HBCU-UP websites.
